raw_text:
China keeps tight rein on credit
 
 China's efforts to stop the economy from overheating by clamping down on credit will continue into 2005, state media report.
 
 The curbs were introduced earlier this year to ward off the risk that rapid expansion might lead to soaring prices. There were also fears that too much stress might be placed on the fragile banking system. Growth in China remains at a breakneck 9.1%, and corporate investment is growing at more than 25% a year. The breakneck pace of economic expansion has kept growth above 9% for more than a year. Rapid tooling-up of China's manufacturing sector means a massive demand for energy - one of the factors which has kept world oil prices sky-high for most of this year. In theory, the government has a 7% growth target, but continues to insist that the overshoot does not mean a "hard landing" in the shape of an overbalancing economy. A low exchange rate - China's yuan is pegged to a rate of 8.28 to the dollar, which seems to be in relentless decline - means Chinese exports are cheap on world markets. China has thus far resisted international pressure to break the link or at least to shift the level of its peg. To some extent, the credit controls do seem to be taking effect. Industrial output grew 15.7% in the year to October, down from 23% in February, and inflation slowed to 4.3% - although retail sales are still booming.
llama3.2:1b: China's government continues to tighten its control on credit to prevent economic overheating.
The move was made earlier this year to ward off rapid price growth and fragile banking system stress.
China's economy is expanding at a breakneck pace, with growth above 9% for over a year.
The country aims for a 7% growth target, but the government insists that any overshoot does not lead to a "hard landing".
llama3.2:3b: China's credit curbs will continue into 2005 as part of efforts to curb overheating growth, with a focus on preventing soaring prices and protecting the banking system.
The country's rapid expansion has led to high oil prices and concerns about an overbalancing economy.
China's manufacturing sector is driving growth, but credit controls seem to be slowing inflation, with industrial output growing 15.7% in October, down from February, and inflation at 4.3%.
gemma2:2b: China will continue its efforts to control credit expansion into 2005 to avoid economic overheating.
Rapid growth of around 9.1% is driven by increased corporate investment and a strong manufacturing sector that demands energy, leading to global oil price increases.
Despite the rapid pace of growth, the government maintains confidence in avoiding a "hard landing" as it targets 7% growth and resists international pressure for currency depeg.
Credit controls are showing some impact, with industrial output slowing while inflation remains controlled at 4.3%.
Retail sales continue to perform well.
qwen2.5:0.5b: China's tight fiscal and monetary policies to curb economic overheating will continue into 2005, state media report.
qwen2.5:1.5b: China will maintain tight credit controls through 2005 as part of efforts to prevent overheating and stabilize growth at around 9%.

This includes addressing concerns about overexpansionary policies risking higher prices and stressed banking systems, despite a continued high 9.1% annual economic expansion rate with corporate investment growing by more than 25% annually.
The manufacturing sector's rapid capacity buildup is driving energy demand, contributing to rising oil prices.
The government aims for 7% growth but remains committed to avoiding an "overbalancing" economy characterized as a hard landing due to high inflation and low exchange rates favoring exports.
Credit controls are seen as partially effective in moderating economic activity despite increased industrial output and falling retail sales.
qwen2.5:3b: China's efforts to prevent economic overheating by tightening credit will continue into 2005, according to state media reports.
Introduced earlier this year, these measures aim to avoid potential price surges while also considering the stability of the banking system.
China’s economy continues to grow at a rapid pace of around 9.1%, with corporate investment increasing over 25% annually.
The manufacturing sector's expansion leads to high energy demand, contributing to persistently high global oil prices.
Despite international pressure, China maintains its pegged yuan exchange rate (at 8.28 to the dollar).
Credit controls appear to be slightly effective; industrial output rose by 15.7% year-on-year in October compared to February’s 23%, and inflation has slowed to 4.3%.
opencoder:1.5b: China keeps tight rein on credit, encouraging slower economic growth with a promise of hard landing growth targets.
The curbs were introduced earlier this year to ward off the risk that rapid expansion might lead to soaring prices.
There were also fears that too much stress might be placed on the banking system, as it is a critical part of the country's infrastructure.
Growth in China remains at a breakneck 9.1%, and corporate investment is growing at more than 25% a year.
The breakneck pace of economic expansion has kept growth above 9% for more than a year.
Rapid tooling-up of China's manufacturing sector means a massive demand for energy - one of the factors which keeps world oil prices sky-high for most of this year.
In theory, the government has a 7% growth target.
However, continued insistence on the overshoot does not mean a "hard landing" in the shape of an overbalancing economy.
A low exchange rate - yuan is pegged to a rate of 8.28 to the dollar, which seems to be declining.
China's credit control efforts seem to be in place and are encouraging slower growth.
The industrial output has grown 15.7% in the year to October, down from 23% in February, and inflation slowed to 4.3%.
Retail sales are still booming despite the increasing competition.
smollm:1.7b: China's efforts to stop the economy from overheating by clamping down on credit will continue into 2005, state media report.
The curbs were introduced earlier this year to ward off the risk that rapid expansion might lead to soaring prices.
There were also fears that too much stress might be placed on the fragile banking system.
Growth in China remains at a breakneck 9.1%, and corporate investment is growing at more than 25% a year.
The breakneck pace of economic expansion has kept growth above 9% for more than a year.
Rapid tooling-up of China's manufacturing sector means a massive demand for energy - one of the factors which has kept world oil prices sky-high for most of this year.
In theory, the government has a 7% growth target, but continues to insist that the overshoot does not mean an "hard landing" in the shape of an overbalancing economy.
A low exchange rate - China's yuan is pegged to a rate of 8.28 to the dollar, which seems to be in relentless decline - means Chinese exports are cheap on world markets.
China has thus far resisted international pressure to break the link or at least to shift the level of its peg.
To some extent, the credit controls do seem to be taking effect.
Industrial output grew 15.7% in the year to October, down from 23% in February, and inflation slowed to 4.3% - although retail sales are still booming.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: China maintains stringent credit controls in its economy to prevent overheating and to address concerns about rising prices and unstable banking systems.
The government introduced these measures earlier this year.
China's economic growth has been robust, at 9.1% annually, with corporate investment surging by over 25% annually.
This high growth keeps the sector strong, above 9%.
China's manufacturing sector's rapid expansion leads to significant energy demands, impacting world oil prices.
The yuan exchange rate is low, benefiting exports.
Despite some resistance to pressures, Chinese exports are affordable on global markets.
The government targets a 7% annual growth rate but prefers it not overshoot negatively.
tinyllama:1.1b: China's efforts to limit credit growth will continue into 2005 as the government seeks to curb the country's economy from overheating by clapping down on loans.

The curbs were introduced in response to worries that rapid expansion might lead to soaring prices, and are intended to restrain demand for goods and investment, which is currently growing at more than 25% a year.

Despite this economic boom, global oil prices remain high due to the massive demand for energy generated by China's manufacturing sector, with overshoot expected not to mean a "hard landing" in the shape of an overbalancing economy.
The government has thus far resisted international pressure to break the link or shift the level of peeg in favor of more stringent controls on credit.
As such, the credit controls are becoming increasingly effective.
tinydolphin:1.1b: China has tightened its grip on credit during the 2005 global economic crisis by imposing harsh limits on both industrial output growth and corporate investment.
This move has been met with skepticism, as it is unclear whether this curtailment of credit will lead to a "hard landing" for China's economy or if its businesses can adapt to the new realities.

Despite concerns about corporate inquiries into their production processes and energy demand growth, China's annual growth rate has remained at approximately 9.1%, and the government's target of achieving a 7% annual growth rate remains unchanged.
In terms of exchange rates, the Chinese yuan is pegged to the dollar, which may further slow down the economy's growth or even lead to fluctuations in global trade.
phi:2.7b: China introduced credit curbs earlier this year to prevent an economic overheating by reducing prices and banking risks.
Despite the high growth rate of 9.1%, they continued into 2005.
The measures aimed at controlling rapid tooling-up of China's manufacturing sector, which led to a massive demand for energy, keeping world oil prices sky-high for most of this year.
The low exchange rate of yuan pegged to $8.28 has made Chinese exports cheap on the international markets.
Despite increasing pressure, China resisted changing its peg or shifting the level, and thus seems to be working effectively in preventing an economic bubble.
However, they still have a 7% growth target.
orca-mini:3b: China continues to keep tight rein on credit by implementing curbs to prevent overheating of the economy.
These efforts will continue until 2005, state media report.
The growth rate remains at a breakneck 9.1%, and corporate investment is growing at more than 25% a year.
However, the government has not abandoned its goal of keeping the economy below the 7% growth target.
Despite pressure from international organizations to break the link between the yuan and the US dollar, China has so far resisted.
The government's efforts to control inflation have led to slower industrial output and retail sales.
hermes3:3b: China keeps tight control on credit to restrain economic growth and prevent overheating.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: China continues to clamp down on credit to prevent an overheating economy and soaring prices in 2005.
Growth remains at 9.1%, corporate investment increases by over 25% annually, and the manufacturing sector's rapid expansion puts a strain on energy demand and world oil prices.
Despite a 7% growth target, the government insists that any overshoot does not mean a "hard landing."
The low exchange rate of China's yuan (8.28 to 1 USD) helps cheap exports in global markets.
Industrial output has slowed down, inflation decreased, but retail sales remain strong.
stablelm2:1.6b: China's efforts to control credit will continue into 2015 to prevent an economy overheating and maintain a 9.1% growth rate.
These measures were introduced earlier this year to ward off risks of rising prices and possible banking strain.
Despite concerns, China's rapid expansion still leads to over 9% growth annually.
The government targets a 7% growth but insists no "hard landing" is imminent due to its low exchange rate – which makes Chinese exports cheap on world markets.
However, the credit controls seem to be having an effect; industrial output increased by 7%, while inflation slowed down to 4.3%.
Retail sales remain strong despite these measures.
granite3.1-dense:2b: China maintains stringent credit controls to prevent economic overheating, initiated this year due to concerns of inflated prices and strained banking system, despite a sustained GDP growth rate of 9.1%.
Corporate investment surges at over 25% annually, fueled by rapid industrial expansion in manufacturing.
This accelerated growth propels high global oil prices due to increased energy demand.
China targets 7% growth but dismisses the risk of a "hard landing" from this pace.
A low-valued yuan keeps Chinese exports competitive internationally, and the government has resisted calls to alter its dollar peg.
Recently implemented credit controls have shown effects: industrial output grew 15.7% in Q4, down from 23%, while inflation dropped to 4.3%.
chatgpt-4o-latest: China will continue its credit restrictions into 2005 to prevent economic overheating, control inflation, and protect its banking system.
Despite these measures, growth remains high at 9.1%, with corporate investment exceeding 25% annually.
Rapid industrial expansion has driven strong energy demand, contributing to high global oil prices.
Although the government targets 7% growth, it denies risks of an economic "hard landing."
The yuan remains pegged to the dollar despite international pressure to adjust its value, keeping Chinese exports competitive.
Credit controls appear to be working, as industrial output growth has slowed from 23% in February to 15.7% in October, and inflation has eased to 4.3%, though retail sales remain strong.
